title: Presidential suite? Inside the Washington DC hotel where the Obamas stayed for a fortnight before Barack's inauguration
text:
View
comments
Just across from the White House, in the basement of the imposing Hay-Adams Hotel, lies the Off The Record bar.
For Westminster correspondents like myself, it’s the nearest thing in Washington to the Strangers’ Bar in the Commons, where MPs and journalists gather for a gossip.
Except this being the US of A, the chat is not over a pint but a classic Manhattan – Ambler Old Scout rye whiskey with sweet vermouth and angostura bitters.
Location, location, location: The view of the White House from the Hay-Adams Hotel
Sitting in the plush banquettes, this is where journos hope to find out from political contacts who’s plotting against whom.
Maybe I’ll even strike lucky and Barack Obama will make the short stroll across from the White House and tell me what he really thinks of David Cameron.
After all, the Obamas lived at the Hay-Adams for a fortnight before his inauguration.
Built in the 1920s, the Hay-Adams prides itself on having the intimate atmosphere of a private mansion. There is nothing so vulgar as a hotel sign outside: just a few flags.

Rare photographs show the fascinating early days of London's... Its proud boast that ‘the only thing overlooked is the White House’ is borne out as we reach our room – we have a prime view of Chez Obama.
Even if it’s unlikely that the famously abstemious Obama will pop in, maybe one of the bar’s regulars, the President’s former spin doctor David Axelrod, will turn up.
Perhaps Axelrod, who advised Ed Miliband in the run-up to our Election in May, will tell me (off the record, of course) what he really thought of Red Ed’s ludicrous ‘Edstone’ and where it is hidden.
Unbeknown to me, my partner Jenni – more interested in shops than political stories – has just got closer to the Obamas than I have.
The hotel’s Off The Record bar. The Obamas lived at the Hay-Adams hotel for a fortnight before Barack's inauguration
As I reel off my failed endeavours, she casually reveals that she saw Obama’s daughter Malia just a couple of blocks from the hotel.
I intensify my research – in other words, it’s back to Off The Record for another drink.
Any politicos in tonight, I ask David the barman? ‘No.’
Any well-known Brits been in lately? ‘Yeah, Charles and Camilla a few weeks back – oh, and Tony Blair.’ Impressive.
By the third day of our stay, I am giving up hope of tracking down a Watergate-style scoop. Back to Off The Record.
‘Don’t tell me,’ I say to David. ‘No politicos.’
‘Actually, you missed Axelrod by two minutes,’ he drawls. ‘He was with Robert Gibbs [Obama’s former press secretary]. Axelrod had two Heinekens, Gibbs one.’
The ‘hold the front page’ moment I could have teased out of Axelrod flashes by.
The president’s daughter Malia, who was seen a couple of block away from the hotel during Walters' visit
I slink away, defeated, and we take the train to New York for two days at the Lowell Hotel, perfectly placed between Central Park and the boutiques of Madison and Fifth Avenues.
I can go for long walks in Central Park brooding over Axelrod while Jenni browses in Bloomingdale’s.
When I catch up with her for a coffee, I am relieved to see that she is not loaded down with bags from Jimmy Choo.
Compared to the Hay-Adams, the Lowell’s lobby is tiny, but it compensates with subtle and stylish fabrics, and the most athletic bellhop in Manhattan.
When we needed a cab to catch our BA flight home, he sprinted four blocks to flag one down.
We leave the US empty-handed but luxuriating in the memory of the heavenly Hay-Adams and the lovely Lowell. Who needs scoops? Or Choos for that matter.
